data.text: giysi yıkama postu için ek yorumlar
How do you wash and dry a set of clothes from one day to the next if you're not in a hotel?
On the radiator
data.author: Allan Galloway

data.text: how do you carry a radiator on a tour? How do you power it etc?
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: sorry Andy I read the question wrong
data.author: Allan Galloway

data.text: If camping and it is dry put on the washing line if that is possible get become accustomed to wet clothes
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: nooo wearing wet clothes will just invite sickness 😅
data.author: Martty Marty

data.text: I have been in the field for weeks, dayclothes are generally, dry at night. If you maintain personal hygiene sop’s it’s no issue
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: To be honest if it’s 3/4 days I don’t wash them. Just pack shorts and wet wipes, the the rest re use. As long as they are the right fabrics, merino etc the they will be fine. Same principle as Glastonbury festival. 🙂
data.author: Graham Bullman

data.text: Take one pair light shorts, top, underwear. Find water, buy or have little washing powder. Change somewhere public toilets where id wash. Hang on bike to dry.
data.author: Naz Whicker

data.text: Wash them and dry them at home.
data.author: Edward John Lait

data.text: Me and my son did 10 days in Scotland after a few days we found a laundromat had a service wash lucky for us there was a cafe next door
data.author: Gary Montana Wright

data.text: Have two sets. Wash at the end of the day and dry overnight. Finish off the drying on the back of the bike when cycling the next day
data.author: Doug Washburn

data.text: my thoughts exactly. And for short trips of 2 or 3 days, don’t worry about it!
data.author: Dan Dennehy

data.text: Swim in a river at night. Bungee cord them to your bike and dry as you ride. You only ever need two sets of cycling gear. I just make sure to use synthetic fabrics that don't hold moisture and dry quickly
data.author: Nathan Pictor

data.text: For a week I don't bother - just dip in the sea/loch/river each night For longer wash one (hand wash in burn etc - take marine friendly soap) and wear one and dry as above
data.author: Rosie Baxendine

data.text: If it’s summer/warm trips you can put the damp, wrung out, clothes in the sleeping bag with you. It’ll be a bit clammy but it does a decent job of drying stuff out. Providing you are wearing modern fabrics with decent synthetic chamois etc it’s no biggie if you set off a bit damp.
data.author: Mark Bradshaw

data.text: We're camping at the moment. I wash everything as soon as I've showered each night, and hang on my washing line (string!) over night. If it's not dry in the morning I strap it to my bike panniers as I ride. You can see stuff dangling in this photo if you look carefully. Here in France it's very dry and very dusty so I'm tending to carry damp washing and dry at lunchtime if I have to. Having quick drying clothes is key - synthetic fabrics dry fastest. Merino wool is slower but smells less. Very thin cotton also dries quite fast.
data.author: Rachel Healey

data.text: hi, what solar power pack are you using? Is it good?
data.author: Margaret Houghton

data.text: its the Big Blue, and yes I'd say it's fine so long as the sun's out!
data.author: Rachel Healey

data.text: Depends how light you’re travelling. Hand wash/ washing up liquid or shampoo to wash, bit of para cord for a make shift line or dry on the bike if take spare. If not dry on body!
data.author: Robert Iredale

data.text: If they’re still a bit damp I just wear them - they’re dry within a couple of minutes
data.author: Graham Cullen

data.text: If out on longer tri ppl s arrange a resupply and a collection bag with a courier . Works well if you have precooked into a specific camp site
data.author: Warwick Neville

data.text: Trip and pre arrange even . Damp predictive text
data.author: Warwick Neville

data.text: Damp predictive text?
data.author: Neville Street

data.text: For a few days I don't bother, just take a spare pair of inner shorts.
data.author: Emma Downey

data.text: I use super market toilets. Like tescos. They are usually super clean and always have hot water. So i wash a few items of clothes and if im in need ill wash my hair also. Oh and you can get them virtually dry using the hand dryer. Yes you do get the odd look from people now and again, but noone minds..
data.author: Paul Wood

data.text: K
data.author: Paul Wood

data.text: Take some hand wash with uou and wash them ASAP, hang out to dry
data.author: Leslie Anstee

data.text: Simple you don’t. Or you put them back on wet. Get in your sleeping bag wet you’ll be dry in the morning. 👍. Same shorts for the whole trip. 😎
data.author: Alex Blake

data.text: Micro fibre towel don’t need to be dry to work - keep a nice shower gel doused in the towel . Two sets of cycle clothes - I shower in the one I used each day - simps
data.author: John DC

data.text: Easy 4 days in the same set
data.author: Stephen Mac Donald

data.text: Wet wipe shower 🚿
data.author: Stephen Mac Donald

data.text: wring out well, hang during ride, hang on line (if you have one) between bike and tent (when arriving early afternoon); don't hang outside overnight, hang in tent; if it's not micro/tech it probably won't dry in 1-day/overnight .. or use a hand dryer somewhere
data.author: Lincs Hcrib
Lincs Hcrib

data.text: neat!
data.author: Sarah Dee

data.text: a bike stand comes in handy and it's just a line looped around the saddle post with carabineers to clip to tent
data.author: Lincs Hcrib

data.text: Wash with a Scrubba bag when stopped for the night & if not dry in the morning strap it to the top of a bag or similar
data.author: James Elias

data.text: Only ride in sunny countries
data.author: Bridget McGill

data.text: Do hotels & b&b where at all possible - you’ll never look back 🤪
data.author: Michael John

data.text: I don't. I have two sets of clothing - cycling and camp/sleeping. Cycling stuff, you just put on wet. Uncomfortable for the first ten minutes, but once you get going, it's fine, provided it's the right kind of clothing. It'll get wet, anyway, from rain or sweat. OK, it gets a bit whiffy in a few days, but who cares? If I have to take a train at the end, I put clean(er) camp clothing on. Now, camp stuff, and especially the sleeping stuff, I am very anal about keeping dry. If it's +5 or so, I sleep in my 'last resort' thermals - the last-ditch layer I'd only use for cycling if in dire straights. And I know some people dry their stuff in their sleeping bags, but I have almost a phobia of getting it wet, earned in all sorts of bad weather cycling, kayaking and hiking trips. The LAST thing you want if things turn rotten, is a cold sleepless night in a wet bag. The thing is, if it's the UK we're talking about, there's hardly ever a chance to dry things once they're wet. It does happen, but prolonged periods of warm, sunny, dry weather are too unreliable, and you can't count on them. So I find it easier to keep wet and dry things separate rather than trying to dry the wet.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: absolutely well said, it’s how we operated in Borneo as I said sir there up in the thread. As long as maintain bodily hygiene no issue
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: Carry a little sring (comes in handy for all sorts) and a few pegs, wash in the shower with your gel or soap dry overnight if not dry tie to the outside of your bike, dry by lunchtime
data.author: Trevor Shaw

data.text: How you finding your little camp chair?
data.author: Andrew Marks

data.text: never leave home without it...it's only a cheap copy from amazon but 3yrs down the line no problems...I didn't think when I bought it I'd use it much but it's much better than a sit mat or the ground.
data.author: Trevor Shaw

data.text: Totally agree. Mine is the same, well comfy and little pockets on the sides, just big enough for my hipflask 😉. Worth that extra bit of weight.
data.author: Andrew Marks

data.text: Water and a bar of laundry soap. Campsites have basins. A piece of string is useful as a washing line, and maybe for other purposes too. Attach your freshly laundered cycling shorts to the rear of your rack to dry in the breeze as you ride. Every so many nights, stay in a B&B or small hotel with laundry facilities or wash and dry in a laundrette (laundromat) while you stay there. Youth hostels sometimes have laundry facilities.
data.author: Mark Severs

data.text: French municipal campsites usually have good clothes-washing basins but next time I'll bring my own plug!
data.author: Peter Howells

data.text: Two sets of clothes. Either hang them to air overnight or wash them in a sink, stream (without detergent), or in the shower with me on a camp site, and let dry overnight. Assuming using quick drying clothing and not thick fabrics that don’t air dry quick
data.author: Mark Vernon

data.text: you need two sets of clothes, if you wash one set every day it will just be dust and sweat to rinse away. Use whatever water you have, river etc, dry them by attaching them to rear panniers as you ride next day, socks go on the bar ends...
data.author: Roland Bai

data.text: Let them dry hanging at the back of your bike!
data.author: Marcolino da Costa

data.text: Inflatable coat hangers. The blown up hanger allows the front and the back of a shirt or T-shirt to be kept apart and allows circulation of air. It can be quite surprising how quickly materials can dry using this method. If you purchase quick dry clothing as well all the better
data.author: Colin Blake
